course.subject: PHYS
course.name: Electricity and Magnetism I
course.description: A physics core course. Electrostatics: electric charge and fields, multipoles, Laplace equation, dielectrics; magnetostatics: currents, magnetic fields and vector potential, magnetic materials; Maxwell's equations.
course.prerequisites: (PHYS 1114 OR PHYS 1314) AND MATH 2023

reviews.author: Tushar
reviews.comment_content: The course follows the book religiously and covers a lot of ground.
reviews.comment_teaching: One of the best Professors at HKUST. I really enjoyed his lectures and his lecture notes are a great complement to the textbook. Lecture videos were also uploaded :D
reviews.comment_grading: Got 10% above mean but ended up with C+ so the grading was not all that satisfactory.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was pretty heavy. We got one assignment every week and had a quiz every week. You need to revise a lot for the quiz and the assignments usually took me one whole day. Expect 15 hours of work outside class I'd say.

reviews.author: L'amour, La vie
reviews.comment_content:
Book used: David J. Griffiths, 4th Edition, Introduction to Electrodynamics, Pearson

Week:
1. Vector Analysis / Vector Calculus, Curvilinear Coordinates

2. The Dirac Delta Function, Electrostatics: Coulomb's Law, Gauss Law

3. Applications of Gauss's Law / Electric Potential, Work and Energy, Conductors, Special Techniques for Calculating Potentials: Laplace's Equation, The method of Image Charges, Separation of Variables 0

4. Separation of Variables I

5. Separation of Variables II, Separation of Variables III

6. Multipole Expansion, Electric Fields in Matter: Effect of External Field on Matter, The Field of a Polarized Object, the Dielectric Displacement, Energy in dielectric systems

7. Magnetic Field: Currents, Continuity Equation, Magnetic Force on Currents, Biot-Savart Law, Divergence and Curl of B, Application of Ampere's Law, Magnetic Vector Potential, Magnetostatic Boundary Conditions, Multipole Expansion of the Vector Potential

8-10. Mid-term plus preparation

10. Magnetic Field in Matter: Diamagnetism, Paramagnetism, Ferromagnetism, Magnetization, The Field of a Magnetized Object

11. Physical Interpretation of Bound Currents, the Auxiliary Field H, Linear Media, Boundary Conditions

12.  Electrodynamics and Maxwell's Equations, Maxwell's Equations in Matter

From the course content listed above, you may think that things are not really that difficult, since you have probably learnt concepts like electrostatics, Ampère's Law, etc, in PHYS 1114. But don't be misled! They are very difficult because they involve a new language of expression - vector calculus. Plus, they are very conceptual, especially for the E-fields in matter and B-fields in matter, where confusing stuffs, like auxiliary field, electrical displacement, are introduced! For me, things I have learnt in PHYS 1114 are nearly useless.

However, you don't have to be excellent in vector calculus, not, at least, in the MATH 2023, the multivariable calculus. The chapter 1 in the book contains all the essential maths you need to excel in this class.(I got a D in 2023, but it doesn't really affect how I use vector calculus.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is pretty standard: lecture powerpoint, homework assignments plus tutorials.

Dr. Rolf Lortz is a standard professor. What he teaches during lecture is useful if you have pre-read the textbook. It is understadable because the content of this course is too difficult that he cannot explain everything in detail for you; it is needed to read the books for detailed explanation. Personally I find the book more useful than his powerpoints. On the other hand, one of the things I like him very much is his teaching style: his teaching pace is very very slow so that you can fully absorb the course material without much stress. He can finish the designated topics for that week and leave few self-study weeks for exam preparation. Perhaps it is German way of life?

The TAs, to be honest, are really bad. I doubt if they understand the course material themselves. However, if you are lucky enough to meet the instructional assistant, Chu Shek Kit, you can learn a lot from him. He understands EM in a profound manner and I often receive very clear explanations from him within few days after sending him emails.
reviews.comment_grading:
It is really fair, but still harsh.

Grading scheme:
Assignments                15%

Tutorial Attendance 5%

Midterm Assessment 35%, Final Examination 45% or: Midterm Assessment 45%, Final Examination 35%

(the higher score will be used to calculate the total score).

Mine:
HW: Average of 80% marks for 7 sets of HW.

Attendance: All attended

Mid-term: 46/50, mean: 35.3, highest:50, lowest:0.

Final: 61/80, mean: 35.3, highest: 68, lowest:10.

Final grade: A

A friend of mine got the same as me in mid-term, 44/80 in final. He gets a B+.

You can see that the distribution of A grade is quite strict. But it is a fair play.
reviews.comment_workload: I would say this course is all about how hardworking you are and how much you like physics. If you find physics interesting, or at least in EM, you will find the content interesting and acceptable. Since the course content is very difficult, you will find it extremely hard to follow the content in normal lecture days if you do not pre-read before the semester starts, especially if you are overloaded with other difficult courses at the same time. Plus, to understand the physics more clearly, you may want to do some problems in the books yourself, in my opinion.(In fact this is encouraged by the professor either.) So the workload is pretty high and you need to be hardworking.

reviews.title: EM I

reviews.author: YoC
reviews.title: An alright course
reviews.comment_content:
Pretty much the standard stuff, everything taught is appropriate, but at times quite difficult. Really have to be fluent with multivariable calculus i.e. line, surface, volume integrals, divergence theorem, stokes theorem, taking curl and divergence of fields.

Topics include electrostatics, fields in matter, magnetostatics, magnetic fields in matter, and electrodynamics with the focus mainly on Maxwell's equations.
reviews.comment_teaching:
A standard way of teaching, going through powerpoints for each topic. Shows several examples of solving problems related to the topic, and just covering all the key concepts that's required.

Though boring at times, explanations are adequate, but often requires students to revisit the topic through textbook in order to fully understand the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading: Not quite sure what to say about this, personally I think the grading system is fair, and pretty standard. Quite annoying that tutorial quizzes also contribute to the grading though.
reviews.comment_workload:
There isn't a lot of work, just one homework sheet every week.

Given that you're aiming to pass though, it'll have to make sure you read through the textbook properly, and that adds to the workload.
